question_text: A 49-year-old woman is evaluated for fever, malaise, and an acute pruritic eruption that began on her face and trunk and then spread to her extremities, as shown. She was previously healthy.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is primary varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infection (Option D). The skin lesions of primary VZV infection (chickenpox) progress over hours from erythematous macules and papules to vesicles. Vesicles often develop a pustular component (as seen in this patient), which then form crusted papules. Vesicles at various stages of evolution are found on the skin. Typically, new batches of lesions appear every few days, originate on the face and trunk, and spread to the extremities. The rash is frequently accompanied by a low-grade fever and malaise.
